As shown in Figure 9, the NCM-811-pristine electrode exhibited an exothermic peak at 208.0◦C with heat generation of 1312 J g−1, while the NCM-811-OC electrode showed the peak at 211.8◦C with a low heat generation of 1302 J g−1. In addition, the second peak at about 275◦C is related with the decomposition of the excessive electrolyte, which is well consistent with the results reported in the literature.32 In spite of the similar heat evolution of the two cathodes, there is still slightly larger peak temperature for NCM-811-OC. In particular, the cation-mixing layers also have a certain effect on the onset temperature of heat evolution for the

NCM-811 cathode material. Notably, the NCM-811-OC cathode exhibits a hysteretic onset temperature, which would directly affect the safety performance of Li-ions battery. It is believed that the enhanced thermal stability could be ascribed to the protection effect of the surface cation-mixing layers, prohibiting the delithiated cathode from being directly contacted with electrolyte solution and thus suppressing the oxygen release and reactivity of the reactive Ni4+ ions.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In conclusion, the nano-thickness cation-mixing layers with Fm-3m structure were formed in-situ on the Ni-rich layered oxide LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 cathode by the surface structural transition from R-3m to Fm-3m at a high-voltage of 4.5 V. The surface cationmixing layers can significantly enhance the structural stability of the LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 cathode materials and effectively suppress the structural transformation from layer to rock salt phase during longterm cycling when the charge cutoff voltage is 4.3 V. The coated LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 delivers higher capacity retention (83% of initial capacity) compared with the pristine (43% of initial capacity) after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. The superior cycling life of the modified cathode material could be attributed to the positive effect of nanothickness cation-mixing layers on the enhanced structural stability of LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 during long-term cycling.
